Hey everybody, welcome to the workshop.
This one is specifically for dealing with mythic.
I don't know how many people have had a chance to play with it before, but there's a lot
of cool features around in here.
And so we want to kind of give an opportunity to go through dive into some of those features
and see how you can spend the time to go through and make your own completely custom agent
that you want to go in and deal with things here.
So this talk is zero to hero, creating your own agent, and we'll go ahead and take a minute
and introduce ourselves.
Let me share some slides.
Here we go.
All right, so I am Cody Thomas.
If you do the whole Twitter thing, I am it's a feature on Twitter.
I created the mythic framework.
So if you guys have any questions at all on what's going on, by all means, please ask
in the chat.
I will try and address anything that's on your mind.
I've been doing a lot of macOS research and operations primarily through my work.
So mythic in and of itself kind of evolved out of that.
I tend to do a lot of macOS stuff.
I've spoken at some conferences, done some things.
I know a couple of you are probably in the new Mac class that we just had the past couple
of days, and you'll realize I have a love-hate relationship with JavaScript for automation.
Mostly hate, but sometimes love.
Hey, I'm Josiah Masari, I go by AirZero24 or AirZero, depending on Twitter, Slack, where
you're at.
I'm also an operator here at Spectrops, focus on our adversary simulation team doing red
teaming, all that fun stuff.
Every once in a while, I try to do some development work, primarily in C Sharp and a bit more

I have made a few agents for mythic framework, most notably the Atlas agent, the first Windows-based

I've also helped Richie Cyrus with his Venonator project, converted that over to Swift for

Coming from the Air Force, I was kind of just a help desk guy, nothing fancy, but I got
out and now I do penetration testing and whatnot, so typical InfoSec career.
Unlike our coworker, Shannon Lucas, I was not a successful musician, so that's how I
ended up in tech, but it's worked out pretty well, so I'm glad that I ended up here, and
hopefully I can help you guys answer some questions and figure this stuff out.
Awesome.
Yep.
So I want to go ahead and start this off talking about what are the goals of this workshop,
what do we kind of expect you to be able to do afterwards.
And so we want to be able to just illustrate how quick and easy it is to create your entirely
own custom from scratch agent, whatever language you want, get a lot of different features
set up in there.
And once you have this ability so that you can go through and make tweaks on the fly
to current agents that exist, or be able to go through and make something entirely new.
Now, of course, there are some caveats to this.
Mythic has a lot of features, so we're not going to be able to cover in this two-hour
time slot every specific one of them.
We're not going to be diving into evasion and stuff like that.
We wanted to pick something that was pretty easy to pick up that most people have some
sort of familiarity with, and just use as a starting point to illustrate the different
concepts that we're going to be going through.
So because of that, we ended up picking PowerShell.
I think by now most people have an idea, at least of what PowerShell syntax kind of looks
like and how you can use this going forward in operations.
So if you guys want to go along and do this workshop with us, there's no requirement that
you do it like hands-on as we're going through and typing things.
All the code and demo and everything is available up on GitHub, as you can see the link down
here, github.com slash mythicagents slash Hercules, so this will be the agent that we're
creating.
But all you'll need to kind of get everything set up and test out is a Mythic instance on
Ubuntu 1804 or above, so have access to that and get that stood up.
You'll need a Windows VM with PowerShell v5, some form of code editor to go through and
edit that along the way as we develop this agent.
You need to have some sort of connectivity between these two things, and then this code,
and so this code has broken out a demo section where we'll be going through the individual
pieces to kind of build the agent piecemeal.
So how is this workshop going to go?
So we're going to do an overview, what on earth is Mythic, maybe you've just kind of
heard the name before and aren't quite sure why should I care, why would I even go through
the trouble of making an agent, talk about some design considerations, we'll go overview
of why we picked Hercules and kind of how it flows about, we'll talk about payload containers
and C2 profiles and how to build commands and agents and talk about some of the features
that you can hook into and just kind of give a big overview of all the different benefits
that you might get from making an agent.
So what is Mythic?
So Mythic is an open source project out there on GitHub, you can find the link here up at
the top.
It is a Red Team framework, kind of came out, hit its heyday in that year of the C2 2019,
like pretty much everybody has a C2 framework coming out there.
But this one I think is a little bit different in that it is heavily Dockerized, so not just
the entire thing in one Docker container, every individual piece is kind of broken out
and I'll give an example of what that looks like on the next slide.
But to help with this, I released a YouTube series and so you can see the link up here.
It's a short playlist of I think, 12 videos now, that just kind of go through step by
step of how does it look to install Mythic overall, what are the different configuration
things you can set?
How do you create agents?
How do you deal with operators?
How do you issue tasking?
All this sort of stuff.
So it's short little videos, I don't think any of them go longer than maybe 10 minutes,
just illustrating these different components.
And so there's a lot of different stuff that's going on in here.
But at the end of the day, you as an operator, just have to connect in with a browser.
So it's pretty easy, you don't have to worry about any sort of crazy dependencies on your
host system to be able to connect in.
So I mentioned there's a lot of different containers and everything that's going on.
And so it can get kind of confusing as you start talking about all these things being
nested and talking to each other and you have like HTTP traffic and RabbitMQ traffic and
like data and everything going around everywhere.
So it's nice to have a kind of grounded diagram to see what's going on.
So if we look here in the center, there's this mythic server, this is kind of the main
brains the operation, it's just a Python server that goes through and acts as the main interface
for our operator web view that you're hitting with your browser, as well as the main thing
that's interfacing with the database and getting all this messages tasking out into the different
containers.
So this mythic server is in its own Docker container, it has a Postgres database in its
own Docker container, which is how we're storing everything for this.
There is a special documentation container that's set up there as well.
So you can have a more verbose and illustrated set of documentation for all of your commands.
Makes it kind of nice to have it out of the way from the main UI as you're going through
doing things.
Now, the other side of this is every payload type that you have.
So like Josiah mentioned, Atlas, there's the AppFile agent, if you've seen the stuff that
Dwight posted recently with the Apollo agent, all these things have their own entirely custom
Docker container.
And so this is one of the things that we'll be talking about today of when you create
your own payload type, you get to control your environment.
And so all of these you can see over here are in their own containers separated.
You can have all of them enabled, you can have some of them enabled, it's really up
to you what ones you want to include in your in your setup.
The same sort of thing applies to your C2 profiles.
So C2 profiles all exist in their own separate Docker containers.
And they act kind of like mini redirectors.
Their whole point is to capture traffic coming back from an agent, either just blindly forwarded
along to the mythic server, like the standard HTTP server does.
Or if you want to do something more custom, you want to do steganography over Twitter,
you want to do binary protocols, you want to do some sort of malleable C2 like we have
with the dynamic HTTP C2 server.
You can have this sort of stuff set up in there.
And then in this Docker container, do whatever magic that you want in whatever language that
you want to switch things back and forth into the main format that mythic is expecting for
a message.
So that's a lot of different stuff about mythic and kind of how it works.
But why would you bother making an agent?
Like what's the point?
What do you get for working with the mythic framework overall?
So I think there's a bunch of things that you get out of it.
And I wanted to highlight a few of them here.
So mythic is really designed for more modern red teams.
The point of that being is it's not just around the agent itself, it's more holistic as to
modern multi user red team operations.
So all operators have their own login, their own preferences, you can pick how you know,
view your view, your colors, or UTC timestamps, localized, all that sort of stuff.
Operators have roles in specific operations.
So you can group out a specific operation that only has a subset of operators and the
other operators are off doing their own operation on the same server.
And all that sort of information is segregated from each other.
You can go through and have operators in specific operations that have restricted capabilities.
So maybe you want to block, you know, a newer member from doing injection capabilities or
from accidentally exiting your callback or doing things that are not OPSEC safe, but
you don't want to apply those limitations to the other operators as well.
So you can have this level of granularity to down to specific commands and specific
operators.
So it's pretty nice to have that kind of control just in an operation perspective.
You can even go one step further and make operators a spectator in an operation where
they can't do anything, they can't create anything, task anything, delete anything,
they really are just there to see what's going on, look at the information and just
absorb.
Additionally, all the techniques that we have in Mythic and all the agents and tasking and
commands and stuff that they are creating are mapped to MITRE ATT&CK.
So you can view this in the ATT&CK Navigator style view to see all of what's possible for
your agents to do, as well as everything that your agents have done so far.
So you can kind of see that real time update of what's going on.
There's a scriptable front end user interface where you can go through and we'll talk about
this a little bit later with browser scripts, completely control the UI and add in your
own tables and pop ups and links and really make your agent experience your own.
You're also able to go through and even like filter the UI so you only see your tasking
or you only see tasking for certain ranges or only things that have comments or a lot
of this different kind of quality of life to filter out the noise of what's going on
in an operation.
There's also a bunch of quality of life improvements, like being able to comment on tasks, being
able to search across an operation and go, I remember at one point somebody ran a command
that told me something about this URL that had this word in it or something, where you
can just search across all the output that you've received in the operation via regex
trying to find what that was and immediately brought back into the context of where that
was seen back with the operation, with the browser scripts, with the whole tasking, everything
right there.
So it's a handy way to go through and find those exact moments that you're looking for.
There's file browser support that you can go through and use a GUI to browse file systems.
There's SOC support, you can go through and have unified viewings for things like file
browser data and process listings.
So it doesn't just live in your specific view of the world, it's shared across all of your
operators and you can search through it.
There's an eventing system where you can chat with different operators or raise warnings
like, hey, this is a thing that might get us caught, we need to be cognizant of this.
And there's even detailed artifact tracking, so you can tell whenever you do a process
that spawns a new process, maybe a sacrificial process or anything like that, you can record
what that PID was of that process that you spawned.
You can record what files are temporarily being dropped on disk as you go through and
you do operations and get that reported back into Mythic, so it's easy for you to go through
and do things like deep inflictions.
So that's just some of the highlights of things I think that make Mythic a great framework
for you to spend some time in as you go through making some new agents or making tweaks to
the current agents.
Now as we go through and we start looking at this, what is kind of required whenever
we start talking about an agent, like a payload type?
What does this kind of boil down to?
So there's just a couple of pieces, so there is a payload container, and so this can either
be a local Docker container that you have set up within Mythic, it can be a Docker container
on another server, it could just be a complete other VM, it could be a complete other host.
You're able to turn all these sorts of things into a like quote unquote Mythic supported
container that you can then create agents, do tasking, all this sort of stuff through
there.
So it really expands out your ability there.
You need a special builder function that will go through and take all the information
that an operator specifies when creating an agent, like what commands they want stamped
in, what C2 profile, where do things call back, like all that sort of information.
That gets passed to your agent, and then it's up to you to figure out how to make it.
So some agents will go through and compile things, some agents will just make scripts,
like it's up to you how you want to go ahead and do this.
You of course need to include your agent code, and then you need to include this special
set of Python files that are about these agent functions.
And we'll talk about this a little bit later, of how you can go through and have a lot of
control whenever you get a tasking for your own agent of what you want to do with it.
And this is one of the areas where you get a lot of possibilities, and it's really just
up to your own imagination of what you can script out for it.
Okay, so when we're looking at developing a new agent, really at the end of the day,
all we're doing is starting a new software development project, right?
So before you really dive in and start writing code and testing things, you need to step
back and do some planning, figure out why are we making this, in what way, and what
do we want to accomplish, what are the goals we're trying to achieve, right?
So when we're trying to make an agent, we need to really consider a few main things.
One is, what are we trying to support?
What operating systems are we trying to have this agent be able to run on, be able to target,
and whatnot?
This is really going to affect most of your decisions after that point.
So if we were looking at Windows, obviously, you're not going to be using an Objective-C

So you really got to think about what you're trying to actually achieve there.
Once you actually figure out where you're going with that, you can decide on what languages

As I said, with Windows, you could have C or C++, you could use C Sharp, there's PowerShell,

But if you're looking at Mac OS, you might have a bit more limited set.
You'd have to use either Objective-C or Swift, possibly JXA, or doing some other kind of
cross-compilation with some other language.
Sorry, one second.
No, no, he's fine.
Sorry.
So anyway, so once you figure out what operating system you're targeting, you can figure out
what languages are then supported by that OS, and then you can decide what language
really fits your goals.

If you don't need that much control and you're just trying to get an agent kind of up and
running, you can do something that's a bit less heavy on the development side, using

It's a little easier to get up and going.

So, another thing to consider, depending on what language you decide to create the agent
in, does that language require compilation?
And I think it actually says complication, so my bad, that's a typo.
But does that agent need to be compiled?
If it's C, it's C++, you're going to have to compile that with GCC or some other compiler.
If it's just JXA, if it's JavaScript or, like, PowerShell, it's just a scripting language.
You don't necessarily need to compile it, because you can just run it through an interpreter.

So, where this really comes into play is when we look at our payload's Docker container,

So, if we need to compile it, we need to be able to build a Docker container that can

So, the first thing is really C2 profiles.
As Cody mentioned, those are like the transports, if you will.
What kind of communication is that agent doing to get to Mythic?
This is just a side note from my experience.
One big thing about the agent comms is if you're using a language and you're not going

Sorry, I lost my thought.

One note on that is that you can customize C2 profiles if you need to manipulate data

You can do that.
You have that flexibility.

So, another part that Mythic supports is dynamic loading of commands.

So, that's definitely something to consider, whether you can actually support that or whether

So, the last part is any additional features.
As Cody mentioned, there's a lot of features that Mythic supports for agents.

So, we are going to be creating Hercules, is what the agent is called that we're going

So, we're also going to be supporting dynamic loading.
